metadata.metaValue:
Create common outputs that will be used
throughout the graph.

Determine which points are inside the
collision mesh. While we're at it, grab the
average hit normals.

Instead of resolving direct collisions with
the point's normals, calculate an average
normal to use for nicer more even deformation.

Resolve verts with direct collisions against
the collision mesh. Also get an array of all
hit distances to determine how much to push
indirect collisions.

Resolve all verts that didn't have direct
collisions to be pushed away using their
normals. This will create a squishy effect.

Working for verts that have direct collisions,
do a loop that will grab new neighbors on
each iteration.

Get better deformations by smoothing verts
with direct collisions and their neighbors.

Do a linear blend between starting and
ending positions.

A common issue using the raycast method to determine if a point is inside a mesh is that the raycast could hit right at a vert/edge and detect as a single hit, which makes it think
it's inside the mesh. A way to get around this is to shoot another ray at a random direction. Both results must return true to be inside. Not completely bulletproof but does make
popping much more stable.
The direciton must have a tiny offset in order to hit the next face
Shoot a ray and extract its hit position
Increase the hit count if there was one
Determine if the point is inside the mesh
Append the hit to the arrray
